string-array.name: science_facts_array
string-array.item: The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792 kilometers per second.
The human body contains about 37.2 trillion cells.
The Earth\'s atmosphere is composed of approximately 78% nitrogen and 21% oxygen.
The dinosaurs went extinct around 65 million years ago.
The universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old.
Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius (212 degrees Fahrenheit) at sea level.
The Great Barrier Reef is the largest coral reef system in the world.
The human brain contains about 86 billion neurons.
Mount Everest is the highest mountain above sea level, standing at 8,848 meters (29,029 feet).
The process of photosynthesis is how plants convert sunlight into energy.
Gravity is the force that attracts objects toward the center of the Earth.
Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections.
The theory of relativity was developed by Albert Einstein.
Viruses are microscopic infectious agents that can cause diseases in living organisms.
The Amazon Rainforest is the largest tropical rainforest in the world.
Newton\'s laws of motion describe the relationship between an object\'s motion and the forces acting on it.
The human body has 206 bones.
Sound travels faster through solids than through liquids and gases.
The Earth orbits the Sun once every 365.25 days.
The Milky Way galaxy is estimated to contain over 100 billion stars.
The process of nuclear fusion powers the Sun and other stars.
The human DNA contains approximately 3 billion base pairs.
The study of fossils is called paleontology.
The theory of evolution was proposed by Charles Darwin.
Thunderstorms are caused by the rapid expansion of air heated by lightning.
Chlorophyll is the pigment in plants that gives them their green color and enables photosynthesis.
The first moon landing occurred on July 20, 1969, during the Apollo 11 mission.
Electricity is the flow of electrons.
Acids have a pH less than 7, while bases have a pH greater than 7.
Plate tectonics is the theory that describes the movement of the Earth\'s lithospheric plates.
Marie Curie discovered radium and polonium and was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize.
Atoms are composed of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
The ozone layer protects the Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation.
Archimedes\' principle states that an object submerged in a fluid experiences a buoyant force equal to the weight of the fluid it displaces.
Humans share about 98% of their DNA with chimpanzees.
Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe.
Albert Einstein\'s equation E=mc^2 relates mass and energy.
The Andromeda galaxy is the closest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way.
The process of sublimation occurs when a substance transitions directly from a solid to a gas without passing through the liquid state.
Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that contributes to global warming.
The pH scale is a logarithmic scale used to measure the acidity or alkalinity of a solution.
Leonardo da Vinci sketched designs for a flying machine called an "ornithopter."
Light travels faster than sound, which is why we see lightning before we hear thunder.
The Hubble Space Telescope has provided astronomers with valuable insights into the universe.
The Earth\'s core is composed mainly of iron and nickel.
Mars is known as the "Red Planet" due to its iron oxide-rich surface.
The periodic table organizes chemical elements based on their atomic number and properties.
Galileo Galilei discovered the four largest moons of Jupiter.

string-array.name: historical_facts_array
string-array.item: The Great Wall of China is over 13,000 miles long.
The Titanic sank on its maiden voyage in 1912.
The French Revolution began in 1789.
The American Civil War ended in 1865.
The Roman Empire fell in 476 AD.
The Black Death pandemic killed an estimated 75–200 million people in the 14th century.
Leonardo da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa in the early 16th century.
The first successful airplane flight was made by the Wright brothers in 1903.
The Declaration of Independence was signed in 1776.
Christopher Columbus reached the Americas in 1492.
Julius Caesar was assassinated in 44 BC.
The Industrial Revolution began in the late 18th century.
The Great Depression started in 1929.
The Magna Carta was signed in 1215, establishing the principle of rule of law.
The Battle of Waterloo in 1815 marked the end of the Napoleonic Wars.
The Cold War lasted from the mid-20th century until the early 1990s.
Albert Einstein formulated the theory of relativity in the early 20th century.
The fall of Constantinople occurred in 1453.
The Gutenberg Bible, the first major book printed using movable type, was printed in the 15th century.
The Mayan civilization flourished in Central America between 2000 BC and 900 AD.
Henry VIII of England separated the Church of England from the Roman Catholic Church in the 16th century.
The Battle of Gettysburg was a turning point in the American Civil War in 1863.
The Renaissance period began in Italy in the 14th century.
The moon landing by Apollo 11 took place in 1969.
The Treaty of Versailles was signed in 1919, ending World War I.
The Russian Revolution led to the establishment of the Soviet Union in 1917.
Joan of Arc played a significant role in the Hundred Years\' War in the 15th century.
The Battle of Hastings in 1066 saw the Norman conquest of England.
The Treaty of Westphalia in 1648 marked the end of the Thirty Years\' War in Europe.
The Great Fire of London occurred in 1666.
The construction of the pyramids of Giza in Egypt began around 2580 BC.
The Boston Tea Party took place in 1773 as a protest against British taxation.
The Berlin Wall fell in 1989, leading to the reunification of Germany.
The Code of Hammurabi was one of the earliest known written legal codes, created around 1754 BC.
Marco Polo\'s travels to Asia occurred in the late 13th century.
The Treaty of Tordesillas in 1494 divided the newly discovered lands between Spain and Portugal.
The Spanish Armada was defeated by the English fleet in 1588.
The Battle of Stalingrad was a major turning point in World War II in 1943.
The Great Famine in Ireland occurred between 1845 and 1849.
The Age of Exploration began in the late 15th century.
The Siege of Leningrad during World War II lasted from 1941 to 1944.
The signing of the Treaty of Ghent in 1814 ended the War of 1812 between the United States and Britain.
The fall of the Western Roman Empire occurred in 476 AD.
The Battle of Thermopylae took place in 480 BC.
The Treaty of Paris in 1783 formally ended the American Revolutionary War.
The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in 1914 triggered the start of World War I.
The publication of Charles Darwin\'s "On the Origin of Species" in 1859 revolutionized biology.
The construction of the Suez Canal was completed in 1869.
The Spanish Inquisition began in the late 15th century.
The Battle of the Bulge was a major offensive during World War II in 1944.
The Magna Carta influenced the development of constitutional law in England.
The Louisiana Purchase occurred in 1803, doubling the size of the United States.
The Battle of Midway was a pivotal naval battle in the Pacific Theater of World War II in 1942.
The fall of the Aztec Empire to Spanish conquistadors happened in the early 16th century.

string-array.name: nature_facts_array
string-array.item: The Amazon Rainforest produces over 20% of the world\'s oxygen.
Mount Everest is the highest mountain above sea level.
Honey never spoils; archaeologists have discovered pots of honey in ancient Egyptian tombs that are over 3000 years old and still perfectly edible.
A single mature oak tree can produce enough oxygen for 10 people to breathe.
The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.
Orcas, also known as killer whales, are actually the largest species of dolphin.
The blue whale is the largest animal ever known to have existed.
The monarch butterfly migrates up to 3,000 miles during its annual migration.
The northern lights (aurora borealis) are caused by charged particles from the sun interacting with the Earth\'s atmosphere.
A bolt of lightning can reach temperatures hotter than the surface of the sun.
Hummingbirds are the only birds that can fly backward.
There are more than 3 trillion trees on Earth.
The world\'s tallest tree, a coast redwood named Hyperion, stands over 379 feet tall.
Caterpillars have more muscles than humans.
Ants never sleep.
Blue whales communicate with each other using low-frequency sounds that can travel hundreds of miles underwater.
Sequoia trees can live for over 3,000 years.
The Venus flytrap is a carnivorous plant that catches and digests insects.
There are more than 1,500 species of cacti.
The Great Barrier Reef is the largest coral reef system in the world.
Bees communicate with each other by dancing.
The pistol shrimp can create a bubble that reaches temperatures hotter than the sun\'s surface when it snaps its claw.
Male seahorses give birth to their offspring.
Elephants can recognize themselves in a mirror, a trait shared by only a few other species.
The fastest land animal is the cheetah, which can reach speeds of up to 70 miles per hour.
Dragonflies have six legs but cannot walk.
Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to avoid drifting apart.
Octopuses have three hearts.
The sun is 330,000 times larger than Earth.
Bamboo can grow up to 35 inches in a single day.
Chameleons can move their eyes in two different directions at the same time.
Penguins propose to their mates with a pebble.
Blue-footed boobies perform a courtship dance involving their distinctive blue feet.
Whale sharks are the largest fish in the ocean.
Orchids are the largest family of flowering plants, with over 25,000 documented species.
Giraffes have the same number of neck vertebrae as humans (seven), but each vertebra is much larger.
The kākāpō, a critically endangered parrot from New Zealand, is the world\'s heaviest parrot.
Koalas sleep for up to 18 hours a day.
Butterflies taste with their feet.
The oldest living tree is believed to be a bristlecone pine named Methuselah, estimated to be over 4,800 years old.
The narwhal, often called the unicorn of the sea, has a long tusk that is actually an elongated tooth.
Arctic foxes change color with the seasons; they are brown in summer and white in winter.
The northern lights (aurora borealis) are named after the Roman goddess of dawn, Aurora, and the Greek name for the north wind, Boreas.
A group of flamingos is called a flamboyance.
Humpback whales create complex songs that can last up to 20 minutes and be heard over long distances.
Male penguins present females with a pebble as a gift during courtship.
The California redwood is the tallest tree species in the world.
Gorillas are herbivores that primarily eat leaves, shoots, fruits, and seeds.
Bald eagles are not actually bald; their name comes from an old English word that means "white-headed."
The Venus flytrap is native to a small region in North and South Carolina.
Albatrosses can fly for thousands of miles without stopping, using dynamic soaring techniques.

string-array.name: coding_facts_array
string-array.item: JavaScript was created by Brendan Eich in 10 days.
The first computer bug was a real insect—a moth trapped in a Harvard Mark II computer in 1947.
The first high-level programming language was Fortran (FORmula TRANslation).
Python is named after Monty Python\'s Flying Circus, not the snake.
Alan Turing, known for his work in breaking the Enigma code during World War II, is considered the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence.
HTML stands for Hypertext Markup Language.
Java was originally named Oak, after an oak tree outside James Gosling\'s office.
Grace Hopper, a pioneer in computer programming, popularized the term "bug" after finding a moth causing a malfunction in a computer system.
C is considered the mother of all programming languages.
Linux Torvalds initially developed the Linux kernel as a hobby.
PHP stands for "Personal Home Page" and later "Hypertext Preprocessor."
Bill Gates and Paul Allen wrote the first Microsoft BASIC interpreter for the Altair 8800 microcomputer.
Unicode supports over 143,000 characters covering 154 modern and historic scripts, as well as multiple symbol sets.
The first computer mouse was made of wood.
JavaScript was originally named "Mocha" and later "LiveScript" before settling on JavaScript.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971, choosing the @ symbol to denote sending messages to other computers.
PHP was originally created to track online visitors to Rasmus Lerdorf\'s online resume.
The first video game ever made was "Tennis for Two" in 1958.
Amazon Web Services (AWS) was launched in 2006, offering cloud computing services.
Ctrl+C and Ctrl+V for copy and paste became popular due to the Apple Lisa computer.
Google was originally called BackRub, based on its original search technology.
Python is among the top programming languages for machine learning and data analysis.
The first domain name ever registered was symbolics.com on March 15, 1985.
HTML5 introduced new features like <canvas>, <video>, and <audio> elements.
Linux is the most widely used operating system for servers worldwide.
Facebook\'s original logo was designed by Mark Zuckerberg and Andrew McCollum using the typeface "Klavika."
Adobe Photoshop was first released in 1990, revolutionizing digital photo editing.
Python\'s readability and simplicity make it popular for beginners and experienced programmers alike.
The World Wide Web (WWW) was invented by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
Java was designed to be platform-independent, with the slogan "write once, run anywhere" (WORA).
MySQL was named after co-founder Michael Widenius\'s daughter, My.
jQuery, a popular JavaScript library, was released in 2006 to simplify HTML document traversal and manipulation.
Microsoft Windows 1.0 was released on November 20, 1985.
The concept of cloud computing dates back to the 1960s with J.C.R. Licklider\'s idea of an "Intergalactic Computer Network."
The first digital computer, ENIAC, weighed over 27 tons and had 17,468 vacuum tubes.
Java was first introduced by Sun Microsystems in 1995.
PHP is widely used for server-side scripting and web development.
Linus Torvalds chose the name "Linux" as a combination of "Linus" and "Unix."
Bitcoin, the first decentralized cryptocurrency, was invented in 2008 by an anonymous person or group using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto.
The first version of the Internet Protocol (IPv4) was deployed in 1983.
The Dvorak Simplified Keyboard layout was designed to be more efficient than the QWERTY layout.
HTML was first proposed by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
Ada Lovelace, an English mathematician, is considered the first computer programmer for her work on Charles Babbage\'s early mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine.
YouTube was founded by three former PayPal employees—Chad Hurley, Steve Chen, and Jawed Karim—in 2005.
Perl, known for its text processing capabilities, was created by Larry Wall in 1987.
The Unix operating system was developed at AT &T\'s Bell Labs in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Steve Wozniak, co-founder of Apple Inc., designed the Apple I and Apple II computers.
The first web browser, WorldWideWeb (later renamed Nexus), was created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1990.
The concept of object-oriented programming (OOP) was pioneered by Alan Kay and the team at Xerox PARC.
The Turing Award, often considered the Nobel Prize of computing, is named after Alan Turing.
JavaScript is used for both client-side and server-side web development.
Grace Hopper is credited with developing the first compiler for a computer programming language.
MySQL, an open-source relational database management system, was first released in 1995.
C++, an extension of the C programming language, was developed by Bjarne Stroustrup in 1979.
Apple\'s Swift programming language was introduced in 2014 as a replacement for Objective-C.
The concept of version control systems (VCS) was popularized by the development of CVS (Concurrent Versions System) in the 1980s.

string-array.name: general_facts_array
string-array.item: Mount Everest is the highest mountain in the world, standing at 29,032 feet (8,848 meters) above sea level.
The Amazon Rainforest produces 20% of the world\'s oxygen supply.
The Nile River is the longest river in the world, stretching over 4,135 miles (6,650 kilometers).
Honey never spoils; archaeologists have discovered pots of honey in ancient Egyptian tombs that are over 3,000 years old and still perfectly edible.
The Great Wall of China is over 13,000 miles long.
Octopuses have three hearts.
The coldest temperature ever recorded on Earth was -128.6 degrees Fahrenheit (-89.2 degrees Celsius) at the Soviet Union\'s Vostok Station in Antarctica in 1983.
Elephants are the only mammals that can\'t jump.
Bees communicate with one another by dancing.
The Earth\'s ozone layer protects life on Earth by absorbing harmful ultraviolet radiation from the Sun.
The blue whale is the largest animal to have ever lived on Earth, even bigger than the largest dinosaurs.
Lightning strikes the Earth about 100 times per second.
Chameleons can move their eyes in two directions at once, allowing them to look in two different directions simultaneously.
Antarctica is the driest continent on Earth; it\'s technically a desert.
The Sahara Desert expands by about 0.6 miles (1 kilometer) each month.
The human brain can generate about 23 watts of power, enough to power a light bulb.
Bananas are berries, but strawberries are not.
There are more trees on Earth than there are stars in the Milky Way galaxy.
Sharks existed on Earth before trees.
A group of flamingos is called a "flamboyance."
Some cats are allergic to humans.
Goldfish can distinguish between music composed by different composers.
The oldest known living land animal is a tortoise named Jonathan, who is over 189 years old.
The Arctic Ocean is the smallest and shallowest of the world\'s five oceans.
Polar bears have black skin under their white fur.
The snow leopard is the national symbol of Pakistan.
The fastest land animal is the cheetah, which can reach speeds of up to 75 miles per hour (120 kilometers per hour).
There are more possible iterations of a game of chess than there are atoms in the observable universe.
Hippopotamuses produce their own sunscreen in the form of a reddish sweat.
The shortest war in history was between Britain and Zanzibar on August 27, 1896, lasting only 38 minutes.
The Eiffel Tower can be 15 centimeters taller during the summer due to the expansion of the iron as it heats up.
Light takes approximately 8 minutes and 20 seconds to travel from the Sun to the Earth.
Human bones are ounce for ounce stronger than steel.
Elephants can\'t jump, but they can run at speeds of up to 25 miles per hour (40 kilometers per hour).
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on Earth.
Sound travels about 4 times faster in water than in air.
Honeybees can recognize human faces.
The human body has more than 600 muscles.
Giraffes have the same number of vertebrae in their necks as humans—seven.
The first oranges weren\'t orange; they were green.
Earth has more than 80,000 species of edible plants.
A single strand of spaghetti is called a "spaghetto."
The unicorn is the national animal of Scotland.
Koalas sleep up to 22 hours a day.
Crocodiles have been around for over 200 million years, surviving the mass extinction of the dinosaurs.
The largest known living organism is a fungus in Oregon\'s Malheur National Forest that covers an area of over 2,385 acres (965 hectares).
The world\'s oldest known animal fossil is from a 558-million-year-old jellyfish.
The world\'s smallest mammal is the bumblebee bat, which weighs less than a penny.
The longest recorded flight of a chicken is 13 seconds.
The shortest war in history was between Britain and Zanzibar on August 27, 1896, lasting only 38 minutes.
Honey never spoils; archaeologists have discovered pots of honey in ancient Egyptian tombs that are over 3,000 years old and still perfectly edible.
Cats have five toes on their front paws but only four toes on their back paws.
The world\'s smallest bird is the bee hummingbird, which measures only 2.25 inches (5.7 centimeters) long.
Octopuses have three hearts.
Koalas have unique fingerprints, just like humans.
Whales are mammals, not fish.
Sharks existed on Earth before trees.
Antarctica is the driest continent on Earth; it\'s technically a desert.
The Sahara Desert expands by about 0.6 miles (1 kilometer) each month.

string-array.name: geography_facts_array
string-array.item: The Earth\'s circumference at the equator is about 24,901 miles (40,075 kilometers).
The deepest point in the ocean is the Mariana Trench, which reaches a depth of about 36,070 feet (10,994 meters).
The highest mountain outside of Asia is Mount Aconcagua in South America, standing at 22,841 feet (6,962 meters) above sea level.
The world\'s largest desert is the Sahara Desert in Africa, covering an area of over 3.6 million square miles (9.4 million square kilometers).
Greenland is the largest island in the world.
The Dead Sea is the lowest point on Earth\'s land surface, located at approximately 1,410 feet (430 meters) below sea level.
Europe is the only continent without a desert.
The longest river in the world is the Nile River in Africa, stretching over 4,135 miles (6,650 kilometers).
The Amazon Rainforest is the largest tropical rainforest in the world, spanning over 2.1 million square miles (5.5 million square kilometers).
The Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia is the largest coral reef system in the world, stretching over 1,400 miles (2,300 kilometers).
The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on Earth, covering about 63 million square miles (165 million square kilometers).
Mount Everest, located in the Himalayas, is the highest mountain in the world, standing at 29,032 feet (8,848 meters) above sea level.
The capital of Australia is Canberra.
The United States has the longest coastline of any country in the world, stretching over 95,000 miles (152,000 kilometers).
The world\'s largest country by land area is Russia, covering more than 17 million square kilometers (6.6 million square miles).
The driest inhabited continent on Earth is Australia.
The Andes Mountains in South America is the longest continental mountain range in the world, stretching over 4,300 miles (7,000 kilometers).
Japan is known as the "Land of the Rising Sun."
The city of Venice in Italy is built on a group of 118 small islands separated by canals and linked by bridges.
The longest international border in the world is between Canada and the United States, stretching over 5,525 miles (8,891 kilometers).
Antarctica is the coldest, windiest, and driest continent on Earth.
The Equator divides the Earth into the Northern Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere.
The Mediterranean Sea is almost completely enclosed by land, bordered by Europe, Africa, and Asia.
The Sahara Desert expands by about 0.6 miles (1 kilometer) each month.
The Panama Canal connects the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean, allowing ships to bypass the long journey around South America.
The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World include the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon, and the Statue of Zeus at Olympia.
The largest island country in the world by land area is Indonesia, consisting of over 17,000 islands.
The Indian Ocean is the third-largest ocean in the world, covering about 70.56 million square kilometers (27.24 million square miles).
The Strait of Gibraltar separates Europe from Africa and connects the Atlantic Ocean to the Mediterranean Sea.
The Gobi Desert is located in northern China and southern Mongolia, covering an area of about 500,000 square miles (1.3 million square kilometers).
The Great Dividing Range is a series of mountain ranges that runs along the eastern coast of Australia.
The Gulf of Mexico is bordered by the United States, Mexico, and Cuba.
The Alps mountain range spans across several European countries, including France, Switzerland, Italy, Austria, and Germany.
The Danube River is the second-longest river in Europe, flowing through 10 countries before emptying into the Black Sea.
Peru is home to Machu Picchu, an ancient Incan city located high in the Andes Mountains.
The Himalayas are the youngest and tallest mountain range in the world, spanning across five countries: India, Nepal, Bhutan, China, and Pakistan.
Victoria Falls, located on the border between Zambia and Zimbabwe, is one of the largest and most spectacular waterfalls in the world.
The Great Lakes in North America consist of five interconnected freshwater lakes: Lake Superior, Lake Michigan, Lake Huron, Lake Erie, and Lake Ontario.
The Atacama Desert in South America is one of the driest places on Earth.
The Bering Strait separates Russia and Alaska by about 55 miles (88 kilometers) at its narrowest point.
The Grand Canyon in the United States is a massive gorge carved by the Colorado River over millions of years.
The Sahara Desert covers large parts of North Africa, including Algeria, Chad, Egypt, Libya, Mali, Mauritania, Morocco, Niger, Sudan, and Tunisia.
The Mediterranean Sea is almost completely enclosed by land, bordered by Europe, Africa, and Asia.
The Appalachian Mountains stretch from Georgia in the United States all the way to Newfoundland and Labrador in Canada.
The city of Venice in Italy is built on a group of 118 small islands separated by canals and linked by bridges.
The longest international border in the world is between Canada and the United States, stretching over 5,525 miles (8,891 kilometers).
Antarctica is the coldest, windiest, and driest continent on Earth.
The Equator divides the Earth into the Northern Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere.
The Mediterranean Sea is almost completely enclosed by land, bordered by Europe, Africa, and Asia.
The Sahara Desert expands by about 0.6 miles (1 kilometer) each month.
The Panama Canal connects the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean, allowing ships to bypass the long journey around South America.
The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World include the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon, and the Statue of Zeus at Olympia.
The largest island country in the world by land area is Indonesia, consisting of over 17,000 islands.
The Indian Ocean is the third-largest ocean in the world, covering about 70.56 million square kilometers (27.24 million square miles).

string-array.name: sports_facts_array
string-array.item: The Olympic Games originated in ancient Greece and were revived in the modern era in 1896.
Basketball was invented by Dr. James Naismith in 1891.
Michael Phelps holds the record for the most Olympic gold medals won by an individual athlete.
The FIFA World Cup is the most-watched sporting event in the world, with billions of viewers.
The Tour de France is one of the oldest and most prestigious bicycle races, held annually since 1903.
Tennis player Serena Williams holds the record for the most Grand Slam singles titles in the Open Era.
Major League Baseball (MLB) is the oldest professional sports league in the United States.
Football (soccer) is the most popular sport in the world in terms of participation and fan base.
The first modern Summer Olympic Games were held in Athens, Greece, in 1896.
Golf is one of the few sports to have been played on the moon, with astronaut Alan Shepard hitting a golf ball during the Apollo 14 mission.
Usain Bolt holds the world record for the fastest 100-meter sprint, with a time of 9.58 seconds.
Baseball player Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier in Major League Baseball when he joined the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947.
Cricket is one of the most popular sports in India, with a massive following across the country.
Boxer Muhammad Ali, known as "The Greatest," was a three-time heavyweight champion and Olympic gold medalist.
Ice hockey is the national winter sport of Canada.
The Super Bowl is the annual championship game of the National Football League (NFL) in the United States.
Figure skater Tonya Harding was involved in a scandal when her rival, Nancy Kerrigan, was attacked before the 1994 Winter Olympics.
The NBA (National Basketball Association) was founded in 1946.
Tiger Woods became the youngest golfer to win the Masters Tournament in 1997.
The Boston Red Sox ended the "Curse of the Bambino" by winning the World Series in 2004.
Simone Biles is one of the most decorated gymnasts in history, known for her incredible athleticism and skills.
The Rugby World Cup is held every four years and is one of the premier international rugby union competitions.
Wimbledon is the oldest tennis tournament in the world, dating back to 1877.
Formula One racing is one of the most popular motorsports in the world, featuring high-speed cars and thrilling races.
The New York Yankees have won the most World Series titles in Major League Baseball history.
Surfing originated in ancient Polynesian culture and has evolved into a popular sport enjoyed worldwide.
Michael Jordan is widely regarded as one of the greatest basketball players of all time.
The Ryder Cup is a prestigious golf competition held between teams from Europe and the United States.
Shaun White is a legendary snowboarder known for his dominance in the sport and Olympic success.
Formula One racing drivers can experience forces of up to 5G during high-speed corners.
Tennis player Martina Navratilova holds the record for the most Grand Slam titles in history, with 18 singles titles and 31 doubles titles.
Soccer player Pelé is considered one of the greatest footballers of all time, winning three FIFA World Cups with Brazil.
The Pittsburgh Steelers have won the most Super Bowl titles in NFL history.
The Summer and Winter Olympics are held every four years, alternating every two years.
The Masters Tournament is one of golf\'s major championships, held annually at Augusta National Golf Club.
Nadia Comaneci became the first gymnast to score a perfect 10 at the Olympic Games in 1976.
The New England Patriots achieved a perfect season in 2007, winning all of their regular-season games and reaching the Super Bowl.
Swimming legend Mark Spitz won a record seven gold medals at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich.
The Stanley Cup is the oldest trophy awarded in professional sports, dating back to 1893.
Alpine skiing features events such as downhill, slalom, giant slalom, and super-G.
The Chicago Bulls dominated the NBA in the 1990s, winning six championships with Michael Jordan.
The FIFA Women\'s World Cup is held every four years and features the top women\'s national soccer teams.
Skateboarding will make its debut as an Olympic sport at the 2021 Summer Olympics in Tokyo.
The Los Angeles Lakers have won multiple NBA championships, led by basketball legends such as Magic Johnson and Kobe Bryant.
Surfer Bethany Hamilton returned to competitive surfing after losing her arm in a shark attack.
The Indianapolis 500 is one of the oldest motorsports events in the world, held annually at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
Boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. retired undefeated with a record of 50–0.
Women\'s soccer has grown significantly in popularity, with major international tournaments attracting millions of viewers.
Cricket is particularly popular in countries such as India, England, Australia, Pakistan, and South Africa.
Swimmer Michael Phelps holds the record for the most Olympic gold medals won by an individual athlete.
Golfer Jack Nicklaus, known as the "Golden Bear," has won a record 18 major championships.
The NFL Draft is an annual event where teams select college football players to join their rosters.
Table tennis is an Olympic sport known for its fast-paced rallies and precision.

string-array.name: technology_facts_array
string-array.item: The first computer virus was created in 1983 and was named the "Elk Cloner."
Amazon, initially an online bookstore, is now one of the world\'s largest e-commerce platforms.
Google\'s first tweet was "I\'m feeling lucky" written in binary code.
The first domain name ever registered was symbolics.com on March 15, 1985.
Apple was founded by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne on April 1, 1976.
The first webcam was created at the University of Cambridge to monitor a coffee pot.
HTML (Hypertext Markup Language) was invented by Sir Tim Berners-Lee in 1991.
Wi-Fi technology was invented by Australian scientists in 1992.
IBM developed the first hard disk drive (HDD) in 1956, which could store 5 MB of data.
The computer mouse was invented by Douglas Engelbart in 1964 and was made of wood.
Microsoft was founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen on April 4, 1975.
The first iPhone was released by Apple Inc. on June 29, 2007.
The World Wide Web (WWW) was introduced to the public by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991.
The first mobile phone call was made by Martin Cooper on April 3, 1973.
The term "Bluetooth" is named after a 10th-century Danish king, King Harald "Bluetooth" Gormsson.
Linux, an open-source operating system, was created by Linus Torvalds in 1991.
YouTube was founded by Steve Chen, Chad Hurley, and Jawed Karim on February 14, 2005.
Adobe Photoshop, the first version of which was released in 1990, revolutionized digital photo editing.
Microsoft Windows was first released on November 20, 1985, as Windows 1.0.
The Apple II, released in 1977, was one of the first highly successful mass-produced personal computers.
The term "bug" in computer science originated from an actual moth found inside a computer in 1947.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971, marking a significant milestone in digital communication.
The International Space Station (ISS) has its own Linux-based computer system.
The computer programming language Python was named after the British comedy group Monty Python.
The concept of virtual reality (VR) dates back to the 1950s, although modern VR technology emerged in the 1990s.
Bitcoin, the first decentralized cryptocurrency, was introduced by an unknown person or group of people using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto in 2008.
The world\'s first 1 GB hard drive was announced by IBM in 1980 and weighed over 500 pounds.
Artificial intelligence (AI) has been a subject of research since the 1950s, with significant advancements in recent years.
Alan Turing, an English mathematician and computer scientist, is considered the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence.
The USB (Universal Serial Bus) standard was first introduced in 1996 to simplify the connection of peripheral devices to computers.
The concept of a "mouse" for computer navigation was first described by Douglas Engelbart in the 1960s.
HTML5, the latest version of HTML, introduced many new features for web development and multimedia integration.
IBM\'s Deep Blue became the first computer to defeat a reigning world chess champion, Garry Kasparov, in 1997.
The term "hackathon" originated from combining "hack" and "marathon" to describe an event where programmers collaborate intensively on software projects.
The first successful 3D printer was developed by Chuck Hull in the mid-1980s, using a technique called stereolithography.
The concept of cloud computing, where data and applications are hosted remotely and accessed over the internet, emerged in the early 2000s.
The Apollo Guidance Computer, used in the Apollo missions to the moon, was one of the first examples of a digital fly-by-wire system.
IBM\'s Watson, a cognitive computing system, famously competed and won in the quiz show Jeopardy! in 2011.
The first graphical web browser, Mosaic, was developed by Marc Andreessen and Eric Bina in 1993.
GPS (Global Positioning System) technology was developed by the U.S. Department of Defense and became fully operational in 1995.
The world\'s first website was created by Tim Berners-Lee and went live on August 6, 1991.
Intel introduced the first commercially available microprocessor, the Intel 4004, in 1971.
The concept of "augmented reality" (AR), where digital information is overlaid on the real world, gained popularity with applications like Pokémon GO.
Apple\'s App Store was launched in 2008, revolutionizing mobile software distribution and app development.
Ada Lovelace, known as the world\'s first computer programmer, wrote algorithms for Charles Babbage\'s Analytical Engine in the 19th century.
Internet Explorer was first released by Microsoft in 1995 as part of the Windows 95 operating system.
The concept of "open source" software, where source code is made freely available for modification and distribution, gained prominence in the late 1990s.
Bill Gates, co-founder of Microsoft, famously predicted the rise of tablet computing and touchscreen devices in the 1990s.
The concept of "big data" emerged as organizations began to grapple with vast amounts of digital information generated by the internet and other sources.
The Large Hadron Collider (LHC), the world\'s largest and most powerful particle accelerator, relies on advanced computing systems for data analysis.
The first commercial text message was sent in 1992, marking the beginning of SMS (Short Message Service) communication.
